And what about MockObjects ?
I've seen an implementation of JMS in their lib.
Actually you would need to get it through CVS.

Jerome.


--- Vincent Massol <vmassol@...> wrote:
> 
> 
> > -----Original Message-----
> > From: Scott Stirling
> [mailto:sstirling@...]

> > Subject: RE: [junit] JMS TestCase anyone ?
> > 
> > No, but determining the requirements is the
> hardest part and you've
> done
> > that. 
> 
> ;-)
> 
> > I'd be interested in testing/using it if you do
> it.
> > 
> 
> Actually, yes, we'll probably write one very soon on
> my current project
> to serve as a functional tester for our message
> based application. I
> just cannot believe nobody has ever written and
> posted one !
> 
> -Vincent
> 
> P.S.: I'm copying James Strachan, he might have one
> ... :-)
> 
> > Scott Stirling
> > Macromedia
> > 
> > -----Original Message-----
> > From: Vincent Massol
> > 
> > Hi,
> > 
> > I was wondering if someone had already written a
> JMSTestCase that
> would
> > help in testing a JMS system, like a
> message-driven application ?
> > 
> > The JMSTestCase would provide helper methods to
> send and receive JMS
> > messages. It could also override the runBare()
> method and
> automatically
> > execute a setUpJms() method before calling setUp()
> (and the same for
> > teardown()). Properties like name of
> queues/topics/JNDI info could be
> > externalized to a properties file and/or as Java
> system properties.
> > 
> > Anyone ?
> > 
> > Thanks
> > -Vincent
> 
> 
> 
>
